Award.AwardTitle: EVOLUTIONARY AND ECOLOGICAL FEEDBACKS: DO LOCALLY ADAPTED SALAMANDERS SHAPE FOOD WEB DYNAMICS ACROSS NATURAL LANDSCAPES?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most ecological research has focused on determining how environmental variation shapes species' abundances and distributions. However, populations also can adapt to local habitat heterogeneity. These adaptations, in turn, can alter species interactions and consequently shape community dynamics. This proposal tests how locally adapted foraging behaviors in salamanders affect food web dynamics in temporary ponds. In southern New England, research has demonstrated that populations of the spotted salamander larvae (Ambystoma maculatum) diverge genetically in their foraging intensities and prey choice depending on the composition of local predators across distances as little as 100 m. This geographic variation in foraging intensity should not only affect A. maculatum's survival with predators but also their interactions with other species in the aquatic food web. Given this background, researchers will examine if and how locally adapted traits influence local food web ecology. Specifically, experiments will test how genetic differences in foraging behavior affect the abundance and growth of organisms in temporary pond food webs by manipulating predators and the genetic constitution of populations in field experiments. Experiments will be conducted with salamanders distributed across local (1-km) and latitudinal (240-km) gradients in predator density. Experiments performed across a latitudinal cline in predator composition will address how the potential northward expansion of predators with climate change might alter northern food webs.

The broader impacts of this work will include training for K-12 educators; involvement of minority summer assistants; training for undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral associates; and enhanced public education in ecology and evolution. A summer internship program will be developed for future K-12 teachers and to mentor summer minority students in scientific research. Three undergraduate research positions will be created and one additional graduate student will be trained. In conjunction with the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History, museum exhibits and public outreach programs will be developed that translate research results into interactive learning units for the public

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: We evaluated how the local adaptation of spotted salamander populations affects the community ecology of freshwater ponds and how climate change-induced range expansions of a key predator affect maladapted prey populations. With this grant, we determined that 1) locally adapted spotted salamander populations alter community diversity, composition, and abundances in mesocosm experiments; 2) microgeographic adaptation occurs in our system through selective barriers against migrants; 3) natural selection from other predator species mediates the predator-prey dynamics between marbled salamanders and naïve northern spotted salamander populations; 4) spotted salamander populations diverge in foraging at multiple geographically diverged metapopulations, but divergence occurs mostly in response to intraspecific density in northern metapopulations; 5) local evolution of foraging rates alters the functional response curves of spotted salamanders by altering their shape and maximum attack rate but not handling time; and 6) different genomic regions are expressed through a transcriptomic analysis of high- and low-risk populations. An independent undergraduate project generated new insights into spotted salamander’s adaptation to local disease risks from water molds. More general papers were inspired by insights from our grant-supported field research. These manuscripts 1) explore the role of species interactions, dispersal, and evolution in mediating the effects of climate change; 2) suggest the importance of microgeographic adaptation in the wild; and 3) generalize Lande’s breeder’s equation to predict evolutionary optima when natural selection from enemies is skewed and suggest why extraordinary defenses evolve in nature.

Broader Impacts: The award has supported the publication of 15 articles with three additional manuscripts in review or preparation, including two in Science, and papers in Nature Climate Change, Nature Communications, Proceedings of the Royal Society B, American Naturalist, Evolution, and Trends in Ecology & Evolution.We trained five undergraduate researchers (4 women; 1 minority student), a graduate student, a postdoctoral fellow, and a lab technician. We trained two K-12 teachers in scientific research, developed K-12 online resources on 1) amphibian migration, 2) prey evolution, and 3) phenology and climate change, developed the ‘Amphibian tracker’ website for citizen scientists, and performed public outreach through the CT State Museum of Natural History, Yale Forest summer seminar series, and multiple visits to K-12 schools. We co-organized a symposium at the AAAS annual meeting and gave 18 invited lectures. We wrote an article on how gender-blind faculty searches could promote women in science for Bioscience and an editorial arguing for political leadership on climate change for the front page of the Sunday Hartford Courant opinion section (“Change has come: Time for leadership,” 12/2/2012).


Last Modified: 11/11/2015
Modified by: Mark C Urban
